API Reference¶

This section documents the public Python API provided by the project.

fbdl.base¶

fbdl.base.convert_nfl_playoff_name_to_int(year: int, week_name: str) → int[source]¶

Given a season and week name, determine the week number of the game.

Parameters:

  • year (int) – The year during which the regular season associated with the postseason game was played.

  • week_name (str) – The game’s name. One of ‘Wild Card’, ‘Divisional’, ‘Conference Championship’, or ‘Super Bowl’

Returns:

The week number that the named game was played during the provided season.

fbdl.base.convert_ufl_playoff_name_to_int(year: int, week_name: str) → int[source]¶

Given a UFL season and a week name, determine the week number of the game.

Parameters:

  • year – The year the game was played. Included for potential future schedule changes.

  • week_name – The game’s name. One of ‘Conference Championship’ or ‘UFL Championship’

Returns:

fbdl.base.get_week_int_as_string(week: str, year: int = None, is_ufl: bool = False) → int | str[source]¶

Given a week’s name and a season, determine the week number of the game.

Parameters:

  • week (int) – The week name (e.g. ‘Wild Card’, ‘Divisional’, etc.)

  • year (int) – The season that the game was played.

  • is_ufl (bool) – A flag used to specify which conversion function is uses.

Returns:

A string, left padded to a length of 2, representing the week number of the game.

Return type:

str

fbdl.base.is_bowl_game(orig_file: Path) → str[source]¶

Given a (properly named) Path object, determine if it represents an NCAA bowl/playoff game and return the game’s name.

Parameters:

orig_file (Path) – The Path object for the video file we’re inspecting.

Returns:

Either the empty string or the name of the bowl game.

Return type:

str

fbdl.base.is_playoff_week(week_str: str) → str[source]¶

Given a short string that was stored alongside a week number in a file name, determine the corresponding pretty representation. :param week_str: The short string that was stored in the file name. One of ‘wc’, ‘div’, ‘conf’, ‘uflchamp’, or ‘sb’ :return: The title cased, full version of the week’s name. :rtype: str

fbdl.base.transform_file_name(orig_file: Path) → str[source]¶

A specialized function that takes a file which follows the naming convention of a specific YouTube channel, and transforms the name to match our convention and play nice with Plex, Jellyfin, etc. :param orig_file: Path object representing the originally downloaded file. :type: orig_file: Path :return: The transformed file _stem_ as a string. :rtype: str

class fbdl.base.BaseDownloader(cookie_file_path: str | Path | None = None, destination_dir: str | Path | None = None, add_yt_opts: Dict | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A wrapper around YoutubeDL that allows for download a list of generic URLs stored in a file.

download_from_file(input_file: Path, dlp_overrides: Dict | None = None) → None[source]¶

Use YoutubeDL to download the videos stored at each URL from input_file.

Parameters:

  • input_file (Path) – The file where URLs are listed, one per line, to be downloaded.

  • dlp_overrides (Dict | None) – A dict storing YoutubeDL parameters to be used for this invocation of download_from_file

Returns:

class fbdl.base.FileOperationsUtil(directory_path: str | Path, pretend: bool = False, verbose: bool = False)[source]¶

Bases: object

A utility class for file operations such as renaming, converting, etc.

update_mp4_title_from_filename(file_obj: Path) → None[source]¶

Using information stored in a mp4 file’s name, update the title stored in its metadata

Parameters:

file_obj (Path) – The file to update.

iter_and_update_children() → None[source]¶

Update all mp4 files in the current directory and all its children.

convert_formats(orig_format: str = 'mkv', new_format: str = 'mp4', delete: bool = False) → List[str][source]¶

Use ffmpeg to convert video files in self.directory_path from one format to another.

Parameters:

  • orig_format (str) – Convert all videos of this format

  • new_format (str) – The new format to store the videos in.

  • delete – If True, delete the original files of the old format.

Returns:

List of file names (stem only) that were successfully converted.

Return type:

List[str]

rename_files(series_name: str, replace: bool = False) → None[source]¶
A specialized method to rename TV series episode files from the format

XYY-<episode_name>.mp4 to <series_name> - sXXeYY - <episode_name>.mp4 Where X is the episode season, and YY is the episode number within that season.

Parameters:

  • series_name (str) – Name of the TV series we should rename files for.

  • replace – If True, overwrite any files which happen to exist with the target name already.

fbdl.nfl¶

class fbdl.nfl.NFLShowDownloader(episode_list_path: str | Path, cookie_file_path: str | Path, show_dir: str | Path, pause_time: int = 30)[source]¶

Bases: object

A wrapper around YoutubeDL that specializes in downloading TV Series available on NFL Plus. TODO: This class requires a lot of work to leverage yt-dlp fully.

ivar base_url: str - The base URL the NFL uses for its TV episodes

download_episodes() → None[source]¶

Donwload the show episodes as specified in __init__ :return:

class fbdl.nfl.NFLWeeklyDownloader(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]¶

Bases: BaseDownloader, NFLBaseIE

A YoutubeDL wrapper that leverages the NFL tools included with yt-dlp. The class (especially authentication + authorization) is a bit messy due to its custom nature. This can certainly be cleaned up.

ivar _api_base_url: str - The base URL of the NFL’s data API, i.e. not its auth API ivar _replay_base_url: str - The base URL of game replays.

get_games_for_week(season: int, week: int, season_type: str = 'REG') → Dict[source]¶

Get the list of games played during the given season and week.

Parameters:

  • season (int) – The season we’re fetching games for.

  • week (int) – The week number to fetch games for.

  • season_type – Currently only ‘REG’ is implemented.

Returns:

The response JSON from the NFL’s API

Return type:

Dict

extract_game_info(game: Dict, replay_types: List | None = None) → Dict[source]¶

Extract only the information relevant to downloading and storing the replays properly.

Parameters:

  • game (Dict) – A dict containing all the information about a given game returned by the NFL’s API

  • replay_types (List[str]) – Which replay type(s) to grab the necessary information for. Must be one of ‘full’, ‘condensed’, or ‘all_22’. (Currently I actually use the pretty string because it’s a bit easier in some ways).

Returns:

A dict containing only the relevant information.

Return type:

Dict

construct_metadata_for_game(game: Dict, replay_type: str, ep_num: int) → str[source]¶

Given information about the game, construct the XML string that will be stored in the related nfo file for Plex/Jellyfin parsing.

Parameters:

  • game (Dict) – The game’s information.

  • replay_type (str) – Which replay type we’re creating the metadata for.

  • ep_num – The ‘episode number’ to assign to the replay. In practice this ends up being the game’s placement amongst all games played in the entire season. e.g. The 87th game played in the NFL season will be 87.

Returns:

A string containing XML information that defines the metadata Jellyfin wants.

Return type:

str

write_metadata_file(game: Dict, replay_type: str, ep_num: int) → None[source]¶

Construct metadata for the given game and store it in an nfo file.

Parameters:

  • game (Dict) – The game to create metadata for.

  • replay_type (str) – The replay type of the video we’re creating metadata for.

  • ep_num (int) – The position of this game in the sequence of all NFL games played in the season

construct_file_name(game: Dict, replay_type: str, ep_num: int) → str[source]¶

Create the video file’s name according to the established format.

Parameters:

  • game (Dict) – Data for the game we’re working on.

  • replay_type (str) – The replay type we’re currently storing.

  • ep_num (int) – The position of this game in the sequence of all NFL games played in the season.

Returns:

The stem to be used in the video file’s name.

Return type:

str

get_and_extract_games_for_week(season: int, week: int, replay_types: List[str]) → List[Dict][source]¶

Combine the tasks of 1.) Fetching the list of games, 2.) Extracting the info we care about.

Parameters:

  • season (int) – The season we’re downloading replays for.

  • week (int) – The week number we’re downloading replays for.

  • replay_types (List[str]) – A list of the replay types we want to download.

Returns:

A list of dict objects containing only the information we need in order to download replays.

Return type:

List[Dict]

download_game(game: Dict, ep_num: int) → None[source]¶

Download all the replay types we specified for this game.

Parameters:

  • game (Dict) – Data for the game we’re downloading.

  • ep_num (int) – The position of this game in the sequence of all NFL games played in the season.

download_all_for_week(season: int, week: int, replay_types: List[str], sleep_time: int = 15, start_ep: int = 0) → None[source]¶
Combine the tasks of

1.) Fetching the list of games, 2.) Extracting their information, and 3.) Downloading the replays

Parameters:

  • season (int) – The season we’re downloading games for.

  • week (int) – The week we’re downloading games for.

  • replay_types (List[str]) – The list of replay types we want to download.

  • sleep_time (int) – The number of seconds to wait between downloads.

class fbdl.nfl.MetaDataCreator(base_dir: str | Path, game_dates: Dict)[source]¶

Bases: object

Create and store metadata based on information stored in file name. Used for replays downloaded before NFLWeeklyDownloader was implemented.

create_nfo_for_season(year: int) → None[source]¶

Create metadata files for all games in the provided year

Parameters:

year (int) – The year to create metadata for.

rename_files_for_season(year: int) → None[source]¶

Add the necessary prefix to file names so that Jellyfin will parse the game replays as TV seasons.

Parameters:

year (int) – The season to rename video files for.
